articles.headline: New Path for Kings of Buyouts
articles.snippet: Private equity bigwigs used to sneer at the idea of investing in public companies. But that was two years ago, when credit was easy.
articles.abstract: Private equity bigwigs used to sneer at the idea of investing in public companies. But that was two years ago, when credit was easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity bigwigs like David Bonderman used to sneer at the idea of investing in public companies. You know, companies that are traded on stock exchanges  the kind ordinary folks buy. Instead, they espoused the virtues, or at least the big rewards, of taking public companies private.

articles.headline: As Price of Lead Soars, British Churches Find Holes in Roof
articles.snippet: The near record price that lead — the stuff many old church roofs are made of — is fetching on commodity markets has led to an accelerating crime wave.
articles.abstract: The near record price that lead — the stuff many old church roofs are made of — is fetching on commodity markets has led to an accelerating crime wave.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDMONDTHORPE, England  Thieves peeled long strips of lead from the roof of St. Michael and All Angels, until a barking dog sent them fleeing from this tiny Leicestershire village. But by then, they had left a hole of about 100 square feet in the top of the 800-year-old church.

articles.headline: Fears That the Market Watchdog Is Losing Its Bite
articles.snippet: With the recent financial crisis some wonder whether the Securities and Exchange Commission has given in to the push to lighten up on regulation.
articles.abstract: With the recent financial crisis some wonder whether the Securities and Exchange Commission has given in to the push to lighten up on regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago the market police at the Securities and Exchange Commission gave JPMorgan Chase the Wall Street equivalent of a traffic ticket. The penalty: $25 million.

articles.headline: Power to Build Border Fence Is Above U.S. Law
articles.snippet: Congress has granted the homeland security chief extraordinary powers to ignore any laws standing in the way of a border fence.
articles.abstract: Congress has granted the homeland security chief extraordinary powers to ignore any laws standing in the way of a border fence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Securing the nation’s borders is so important, Congress says, that Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary, must have the power to ignore any laws that stand in the way of building a border fence. Any laws at all.

articles.headline: There’s Gas in Those Hills
articles.snippet: A natural gas drilling frenzy unlike any seen in decades is unfolding in rural Pennsylvania, and it eventually could encompass a huge chunk of the East.
articles.abstract: A natural gas drilling frenzy unlike any seen in decades is unfolding in rural Pennsylvania, and it eventually could encompass a huge chunk of the East.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUGHESVILLE, Pa.  At first, Raymond Gregoire did not want to listen to the raspy voice on his answering machine offering him money for rights to drill on his land. They want to ruin my land, he thought. But he called back anyway a week later to hear more.

articles.headline: Crackdown on Militias Raises Stability Concerns
articles.snippet: An offensive against the Mahdi Army in Iraq is creating potentially destabilizing political and military tensions.
articles.abstract: An offensive against the Mahdi Army in Iraq is creating potentially destabilizing political and military tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A crackdown on the Mahdi Army militia is creating potentially destabilizing political and military tensions in Iraq, pitting a stronger government alliance against the force that has won past showdowns: the street power wielded by the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Stephen Farrell

articles.headline: CBS Said to Consider Use of CNN in Reporting
articles.snippet: The network has been in discussions about a deal to outsource some of its news-gathering operations.
articles.abstract: The network has been in discussions about a deal to outsource some of its news-gathering operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: CBS, the home of the most celebrated news division in broadcasting, has been in discussions with Time Warner about a deal to outsource some of its news-gathering operations to CNN, two executives briefed on the matter said Monday.

articles.headline: Young Obama Backers Twist Parents’ Arms
articles.snippet: A theme has emerged among superdelegates endorsing Senator Barack Obama: their children made them do it.
articles.abstract: A theme has emerged among superdelegates endorsing Senator Barack Obama: their children made them do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The daily phone calls. The midnight e-mail. And, when college lets out, those dinner table declamations? Oh, please.

articles.headline: Asian Inflation Begins to Sting U.S. Shoppers
articles.snippet: For two generations, Americans have imported goods produced ever more cheaply from low-wage countries. But that free ride may be coming to an end.
articles.abstract: For two generations, Americans have imported goods produced ever more cheaply from low-wage countries. But that free ride may be coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAT TRANG, Vietnam  The free ride for American consumers is ending. For two generations, Americans have imported goods produced ever more cheaply from a succession of low-wage countries  first Japan and Korea, then China, and now increasingly places like Vietnam and India.
